ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Talked about the connection between health and social contexts, very interesting things
A good understanding of historical and current issues in public health
Learned a lot about public health, structure vs. agency, limits of medicine, and networks in this class.

I learned a lot about different areas of sociology and public health - ie., income inequality, health disparities, the impacts of medical care versus public health, and types of public health interventions. I also learned how to think more critically about the determinants of health and the ways we can study and improve public health.
I gained an understanding of a variety of public health topics

This course allowed me to take an introspective and retrospective view of the world of medicine in the given age. I learned a lot about medical practices that are both flawed and highlighted for their specialities, and this year, specifically, I learned a lot about COVID-19 and how it has changed our medical practice in the current day.
Learned about general concepts of public health such as the role of medical care in affecting health, the social construct of illness and medicine, and social networks.

Some class topics include the following: role of medicine and medical care, the impact of socioeconomic status on health, social construction of illness and different standards of health, experience of death, iatrogenesis, different causes of preventable deaths, and the impact of social network in health.
Definitely gained a large overview of what public health encompasses. Improved critical thinking skills.

Greater understanding of the state of medical care in the country/world, what causal factors impact people's health, and their overall quality of life. The consistent tension between structure versus agency.
Insights on public health, reevaluating the role of medicine, reading research papers.
I learned basic information about public health and sociology.

I learned how to recognize patterns in social interactions and possible measures and interventions in public health to take. I learned how to connect course concepts in public health to current events such as the coronavirus pandemic.

This course covers a wide range of topics in public health. Some of the key themes in the course included structure vs. agency and medical care vs. public health, both of which provide an interesting frameworks for understanding health, disease, and medicine in American society. The course also covers Prof. Christakis's own area of expertise: social networks. Finally, there is good discussion of public policy measures and public health interventions-- which makes for great food for thought.
Intro to the health of the public - social networks impact on health heavier, socioeconomic status and health, race and health, inequality and health, etc
I learned a lot about the social effects and causes of health.
A broad scope of public health studies and social interventions. A very enlightening course.

I learned about the ideas of structure vs. agency in public health, the immense and powerful effects of social factors on public health as compared to medicine alone, and social networks and influence we have on each other & our peers can have a dramatic impact on public health.

For the first time, I feel my eyes were opened to a lot of the underlying factors which affect health.  I think everyone should take this class as it provides an eye-opening glance at U.S. public health.  The mix of sociology and public health was intellectually stimulating and the readings were great.
Barely any.

I learned all about public health in general. It was a broad course that delved into a lot of material, and I really enjoyed it. I found it quite cool to learn about the intricacies of medicine and public health that Dr. Christakis was familiar with. Because of his background, he comes with so many interesting anecdotes and stories that really add to the course. If you want to learn about public health, the state of medicine in the world right now, and a broad variety of other things, this is the course for you!
I learned about the fundamentals of public health and some of the basics of network science.
Learned more about public health side of medicine
Learned a lot about Public health.
introductory concepts of public health
public health and recontextualization of medicine
The intersection between sociology and medicine/public health.
Entirely new way of viewing health
Learned to consider health from the perspective of structure rather than agency.

public health very complicated, role of healthcare very complicated, issues in public health can not be reduced down to a lack of healthcare access, sociocultural factors play a huge role, medicalization is constantly evolving, balance between structure and agency is important in public health, context matters for health interventions, an individual's health is easily influenced by others via social networks and cultural norms
This was a good introductory course into public health studies.
Learned to think of the social aspects of health.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength - loved the engagement, his class was so interesting and there were many things that I learned about, he enjoyed student input and was well versed in technology compared to other professors
Weakness - the way he talked about race felt very problematic, many assumptions being made that black = poor, hispanic = uneducated, did not like the vibe that gave off, hated the readings, very uninteresting when the whole concept could be explained in a minute without reading the article
Professor Christakis was a very engaging lecturer. One weakness is that the readings sometimes don't align too closely with what is discussed in class/it is hard to know how carefully to read them

Strengths: Fair exams, incredible lectures. God, I wish I could take this class in person. Prof Christakis was riveting every week and kept even material that I thought would be dry riveting (e.g. I was thinking about social networks for weeks after the lectures on them). I also kinda liked how he bullied people to keep cameras on lol. It was so depressing staring at a screen of random names in other classes. Also not particularly hard, despite the fact that its def not a gut. 

Weaknesses: Pacing of readings could be a bit better - some days it was basically nothing, other days we were supposed to read like half a book (i.e. the book never ended up being read). Not a gut, if that's what you're looking for. Would've preferred traditional final to take-home.

This is a great course. After four years at Yale I can definitely say this is one of the better courses I have taken, as it really changed my perspective on public health. If anything, I'd say the sections could be better structured to be more consistent, and some of the later lectures felt a little disconnected/less relevant. Still an amazing course that is thoughtfully organized and impactful.
teacher mean

I thought that the content of the course was interesting, but many of the readings were outdated. Professor Christakis also had strong opinions and would sometimes become very defensive when questioned by students.

I found no weaknesses in this course, rather I can only speak to its strengths. The lectures were extremely engaging and allowed for students to both learn and reflect on previous knowledge of the medical system to fully absorb the material being taught. That is just one example of the many strengths this course had.
It was a very good course with powerpoint slides, a great professor, and helpful TAs.

Strength: Very passionate professor, especially Dr. Christakis's lectures were fantastic. It would have been even better if the lectures were in person. The head TA (Maggie) is nice and approachable.

Weakness: The review sessions for the 2 midterms are not so helpful. TAs did not prepare any guiding questions, and the sessions were basically students asking random questions that are tangentially related to the class. The final exam (which was two 6 page papers) were a bit overwhelming. Especially if you have other final exams or papers due during the reading week, it is stressful. Not only the final exam required synthesis of a lot of materials covered throughout the semester (which is reasonable) the prompts required a bit of creativity and analytical skills.

Strengths: the readings and lectures were very interesting. 

Weaknesses: Some of the content we covered was very heavy and sometimes would be talked about in class without proper warning. Such warning could help Yale students feel more welcome and more engaged. Though the readings were very interesting, there were a lot. I think shortening the list to key papers in each of the categories would aid in the workload.

Strengths: incredible course contents - super relevant with COVID, but beyond that just as a citizen. Professor Christakis knows so much and it was awesome to hear about just a little of the cool ideas in sociology/public health. Weaknesses: more engaging lectures/opportunity to interact with other classmates. While the lecture was really interesting, it was hard to sit and just listen for 75 minutes. Maybe a little break in the middle of the lecture or a "turn and talk" breakout room type thing to at least meet others in the class would've been nice.
Strength: Professor is more than qualified for teaching the course. Great lecturer, and you can tell he's passionate and knowledgeable about what he's doing

Grading was very arbitrary for the midterms. Lectures were generally pretty interesting and I learned a good deal from them, but I wish section was more interactive/interesting since we never really got into the heart of the critical readings for the class.

Prof. Christakis is not very engaged with the class outside of lecture, and did not have open office hours. Some of the teaching assistant staff did not know much about the class or material and therefore section was not very beneficial. Grading was highly subjective and clear feedback was not given.

The professor is a strong teacher or lecturer and reinforces concepts in the reading well. The course material is complex and interconnected yet easy to digest, due to the way the professor lays out each lecture. Professor is very reasonable and curious, making for a hospitable learning environment. There were not any highly apparent weaknesses with the course. The course could be improved by adding more assignments to gauge student understanding prior to exams, since the only method of evaluation of course material comes from these exams, which may be a hit or miss.

Strengths: Professor Christakis's lectures are well organized and filled with interesting material; almost never did I feel bored by what we were learning. The reading list was equally as interesting. The strengths of this course lie mainly with the course material and the professor's lecturing ability.

Weaknesses: While I understood the good intentions of the new midterm format (read a news article and respond to questions while drawing upon course material), for some questions I found the format confusing. Some questions, in my view, were formulated to cover course topics but did not directly relate to the news article (i.e. the connection between the course material and main ideas in the article seemed forced). Thus, I found myself guessing "what did the teaching staff mean when they asked this question/on what topic are they trying to test us" during the test instead of directly engaging with the course material and article.

Readings and lecture were great and overall a very interesting course! Lots of topics covered in each class and many research studies referenced that helps enforce what we are learning! Very thorough and thought-provoking lectures.
I thought the lectures were well organized and cohesive, but more connections between the lectures could have been made.

The class content is fascinating, and professor Christakis's teaching is clear and engaging.
The reading assignment workload was very heavy.

I think Professor Christakis did a wonderful job in creating this course.  The readings were very interesting and Professor Christakis's energy and interest in the topic shined brightly even through the zoom screen.  Even the tests helped in furthering my understanding of the materials we were engaging with.

The course content would be relatively ok if it was taught by anyone else but Christakis. The professor was arrogant, self-centered, and insensitive. He caused a friend in the class to be triggered so badly she had to receive mental health services and drop the class. On top of that, he was incredibly rigid and not understanding or empathizing at all with students' realities of life this semester. Bottom line: this course needs a new teacher.

Strengths: Maggie, the head TF and Dr. Christakis. Both were absolutely wonderful and so insightful. The class is very interesting because Christakis tied together so many different fields  all within his expertise. I really loved all the interesting examples, and learned a ton! Great great class to learn about healthcare and public health.

Weaknesses: Section. This was one of those classic courses where section was not a party at all. This is not necessarily a reason not to take this class  section is just once a week and we did get the opportunity to discuss things, but UGHGH so boring and so silent. Another weakness is that a lot of the examples are from the 2000s and early 2010s. It would be lovely to refresh some of those examples.

Strengths: Very interesting material, I like Prof Christakis' lecture style, thought the course was well designed, very fair exams
Weaknesses: Some of the readings are very outdated, final was extremely long

Strengths: lectures were very interesting
Weaknesses: sections didnt add much to course
I thought the class was very interesting and interactive

strengths: very engaging and interesting class
weakness: discussion sections were sometime unproductive
Even though the research was very thorough I wish there was more recent studies added to the class to see how the concepts look like today.
weakness - midterms only covered a small portion of the semesters work, rather than the broad scope of topics we learned
This class is wonderfully designed and lectured. The only weakness I would say would be that the expectations for essays could be slightly more explicit.

Strengths:
- engaging lecture
- well-organized syllabus and Canvas page
- options for the final
- fair workload

Weaknesses:
- could have thrown a weekly discussion post or something in the grade breakdown to take some emphasis off of exams
- occasional lack of sensitivity/cultural awareness
I enjoyed the course, but did not appreciate the level of data/statistics involved. With a course like health of the public, I think there should have been a greater emphasis on qualtitative studies.
Excellent and appropriate readings, also superb lectures. Better exam feedback would be helpful.

The course was very well taught, and is a great class to take, especially when pre-med. However there was limited to no feedback after exams, and it quickly became clear that the standard exam style would not work given the switch to open-note exams. This then made the exams harder than I believe they otherwise would have been had it been a regular semester, and I felt like I was getting lower grades than I deserved/earned in order to create a more significant grade distribution. At the very least, providing more feedback would help improve this, but I also think this issue could go away with the return to the normal exam style.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The structure of the course did not seem to consider for COVID-19 at all and instead just pretended that everything was normal, just virtual. No considerations were made for possibilities that students lives and academic abilities might be affected by COVID and to adjust any teaching accordingly.

Success - knew how to use technology, enjoyed discussion section, enjoyed the sharing of slides after yet he took a week to share them 
Weakness - hated readings, very uninteresting, more engagement during class would have been nice, sometimes it felt like I was being talked at and I fell asleep a couple times.
The lectures were strong; it felt a bit hard to ask questions and sometimes breakout rooms could have been helpful
Loved that he made people keep cameras on. Everyone who complains about that here (I'm sure there will be more than a few) is lame.

The course was pretty successful even in a virtual setting. The live lecture discussions were nice, and it was good that the professor encouraged people to have cameras on and be engaged (even though engagement was difficult at times).
The virtual lecture was engaging.
Online lectures were extremely engaging given the unfortunate circumstances, as media through images and videos were used perfectly to capture the audience of this course.

There were instances of calling people out for not having cameras on. Though I understand the reasoning behind wanting people to keep their cameras on, sometimes it wasn't possible to do so (bad connection, extenuating circumstances, etc). Since this a public health class in which we talk about social issues, more understanding would have been nice.
Prof. Christakis tried to make the class participate but I think there couldve been more platforms for involvement such as mini assignments, and more places to ask questions.

Because this class is a lecture, it lends itself well to the online format, so there are not many practices to improve. Students were engaged with the course material because they kept their cameras on. There was a good division between lecture slides and videos presented in class making for a well-balanced course. Discussion sections and office hours were a practice that helped students gauge their learning as well during the pandemic.
In my view, the instructors did the best they could given the pandemic. We even took a few lectures to discuss the COVID-19 pandemic itself!
Keeping video on in class made it feel more like a normal lecture!
I think it was difficult for discussion sections to be interactive.
All was fine... Section was boring because no one would talk on Zoom. Yale should work with instructors to help them "see" students on Zoom, since that was a struggle sometimes.
I thought the course moved to a virtual format well, no suggestions
The professor asked a lot of questions and took questions which I thought was helpful toward the interactive nature of the class
n/a
i think it is a bit inconsiderate to require people to constantly keep their cameras on during lecture. this does not take into account the internet connections or living situations of individuals.

I'm not sure what was done differently in this course during the pandemic compared to an in-person semester. If the final exam was not previously a take-home exam, that was a very helpful change that helped to actually learn the information rather than cram among other exams. I mentioned previously that the addition of a low-stakes assignment (like a weekly discussion board post or some other small assignment) could have taken some of the weight off the exams and been more accessible for students facing anxiety/extenuating circumstances during the pandemic.
The course was virtually engaging.

The switch to open-note exams, while usually beneficial to students, felt detrimental to me. I studied using all the previous exams, and this worked for the first exam, which was most similar to the style of past exams. But after the first midterm, it became apparent that allowing exams to be open-note also warranted a change in the kind of question being asked. Between this and not getting much feedback on exams, I felt like the course actually became harder than it would have been during a normal semester, and I would have preferred exams that were more similar to those of the past and closed-notes, rather than the second midterm we had where the questions became harder. I was left feeling like I understood the material very well, and I studied a lot, but because of the new exam style, this was not being reflected in my grade, which was incredibly frustrating.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
No, I would never recommend this course to another student. The course readings are okay, but Christakis' lectures do not do much to add upon the readings, rather he usually just goes over them.

Christakis himself is also unapproachable and not open to new ideas. He is extremely stuck in his own opinions. In a course that is meant to evaluate and discuss the impact of the role of structures like race and gender on public health, it is disappointing that Christakis fails to realize that as a white male he might have privileges and biases that he simply does not bother to question. 

This course has also much more busywork than it is worth, with two six-page papers as the final exam, which are assigned and released only a week before they are due. Some of the readings throughout the semester are interesting, but it is a lot of scientific studies that are difficult to comb through. This work might be worth it if the course was more well taught, but unfortunately this is not the case.

Yes - engagement was high, interesting things I learned, workload was not terrible, only had papers to do which were midterms and finals 
Pretty great of a class to take
Yes, if you want to learn about US health trends

If you're premed, take this class. If you're doing anything tangential to medicine, take this class. If you're looking for an interesting 5th credit that's not a gut, but not super challenging either, take this class. You will learn a ton - I certainly did. The lectures will keep you thoroughly engaged.

Yes, I definitely would. It's a great class. It's not terribly challenging or demanding workload-wise, so you can actually focus on enjoying what you're learning. The class also has applications to lots of different fields - you don't need to be interested in studying public health to benefit from it.

Yes! This course is extremely interesting and engaging and can allow anyone to learn about the previous/current health system that affects the United States today. This course is not geared towards a specific major, and I strongly suggest anyone and everyone to take this course.
Yes! It is a great intro course and really made me want to take more public health courses.

Yes! I think this class is approachable for any major, and the course teach you content that anyone should be knowledgeable if they live in US. Especially with Covid pandemic, the class content was super relevant!
I would recommend this course for people interested in gaining an understanding and appreciation for public health. The readings are interesting and you learn to think differently.
Yes! Fantastic intro to public health/sociology, especially with Prof. Christakis.

Yes! This is one of those classes that you only get at Yale. Compared with all my monotonous science requirements for pre-med, this class was a breath of fresh air. It was interesting and really insightful, especially if you're going into a medical career.

Would recommend it senior year, or as a credit/d. I thought a lot of the material was biased though and not as scientific as it seemed. Sometimes it felt like prof. Christakis was asserting his own opinion and claiming it as fact, like about how healthcare doesnt change health outcomes.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The course material is extremely interesting, the class is fascinating, and the professor is engaging. There is a reasonable workload, and any student who reads the material and pays attention in class can expect to do well in the class.

Yes. If you want to be a more informed citizen, you ought to take this course. Public health and healthcare are important topics in society and politics, and it would be a great addition to one's undergraduate career at Yale to critically examine these topics.
Yes! Super interesting and thought-provoking material, especially for any pre-meds or people with a public health interest!
Yes, its very interesting.
Yes Professor Christakis and the other TFs are very passionate about what they teach and you'll learn to appreciate public health from new perspectives.

Yes!  For the first time, I feel my eyes were opened to a lot of the underlying factors which affect health.  I think everyone should take this class as it provides an eye-opening glance at U.S. public health.  The mix of sociology and public health was extremely interesting.  The readings were also very interesting and Professor Christakis' interest in the subject is palpable in every class making for interesting lectures.
Not unless it was taught by another teacher.

Yes, for sure! Christakis is a fantastic professor who has an absolute wealth of knowledge. His perspective is unique because of his previous work. The course is very interesting, so are the readings, although I never really had time to read them... The stories and slides were so compelling and I learned a ton. I would recommend this to anyone interested in health, healthy policy, medicine, future-doctors (although I am not one), or just anyone who wants a not-too-hard interesting class.
Yes, it was super interesting!
Yes, if interested in public health its a must take
Yes! Very interesting to learn about Public health
Yes, it's a very interesting class especially if you are interested in medicine or the healthcare system
yes

No, I would not recommend this course. It was, by far, the worst class I have ever taken at Yale. And the reason for this is 100% the professor. He made every class a living hell. The hours felt like months, and it felt like he personally attacked every student he called on. To make matters worse, as if that was even possible, he wrapped up by advocating for eugenics. Maybe he should reflect inwardly about his place on this planet, and take himself off campus. Or take a year off- to reflect and come back with better work habits. Last point: I hate you, Chirstakis.

Absolutely not. This was not the sociology class I was anticipating it to be. Some of the arguments that the professor made were very biased in his opinions.  If anyone bothered to look up the sources of his information on the slides, especially those to convince us that medical advancements have not really improved our health, some of those graphs were from sketchy sources (or were just so pooy cited). Maybe it'll help with the MCAT, but is rather just study for it.
Highly, highly recommend this course. Christakis is so smart and nuanced in his thinking  really important course to take for perspective and with an open mind. Whole new way of viewing health now.
There is an ungodly number of readings assigned for this class but the material is fascinating.
Definitely! Dr. Christakis is an excellent lecturer who presents his students with fresh perspectives on health and social issues.
I think there are other courses related to public health that would be just as good if not better, but if a student were interested in this class I'd tell them to take it.
I did not enjoy the professor, so I would not recommend this course. The work is interesting though.
Yes a fascinating course on something that we all deal with, health. Great professor.

Overall, yes, I would. Christakis is an amazing lecturer, and the material is very useful to pre-meds. However, I do have some issues with the course, although I think these will probably go away with the return to normal classes and exams. The switch to open-note exams, while usually beneficial to students, felt detrimental to me. I studied using all the previous exams, and this worked for the first exam, which was most similar to the style of past exams. But after the first midterm, it became apparent that allowing exams to be open-note also warranted a change in the kind of question being asked. Between this and not getting much feedback on exams, I felt like the course actually became harder than it would have been during a normal semester, and I would have preferred exams that were more similar to those of the past and closed-notes, rather than the second midterm we had where the questions became harder. I was left feeling like I understood the material very well, and I studied a lot, but because of the new exam style, I was getting lower grades than I deserved/earned in order to create a more significant grade distribution; my studying and understanding did not feel like it was not being reflected in my grade, which was incredibly frustrating. At the very least, providing more feedback would help improve this, but, as previously mentioned, I also think this issue could go away with the return to the normal exam style.

I feel like most of the material we covered was fairly obvious, but maybe that's just a consequence of living through a major public health event. With that being said, it was nice to go through the material structured manner, and I found the course's emphasis on guiding concepts such as structure vs. agency helpful in framing what we learned. Take this class if you want to read some interesting papers and learn about public health in a classroom setting, but don't expect to have your mind blown every lecture.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: They recorded classes + discussion section.
n/a
N/A
The class was fully virtual. Two live virtual lectures each week (also recorded and posted on Canvas), as well as one virtual section each week.
live virtual lectures that were also recorded
NA
live virtual lecture which was also recorded and uploaded on Canvas.
Virtual discussion section followed lecture which could be watched live or recorded.
Live lecture and discussion section
Live virtual lecture (also recorded) and other live non recorded virtual section
Lectures were also recorded. Additionally, there were discussion sections held over Zoom.
N/A

In person lectures
Discussion sections
Survey
Live virtual lectures with recorded videos
Live lectures were recorded and there was a live Zoom discussion section once a week
N/A
Sometimes I watched recorded lectures if I couldn't make it to class.
Live virtual lecture plus live virtual section
Section over zoom
N/A
combination of live and recorded lecture
weekly seminar
Virtual discussion sections
weekly discussion sections
live virtual lecture and live virtual discussion section
Virtual section
Discusion sessions
Combination of recorded and live virtual lectures, supplemented by discussion sections.
I also attended weekly discussion sections led by Maggie.
